title: "What are the corollaries of the ancient philosophy of the circle in relation to man's spirit and life?"
first_phrase: In the previous text, the author discusses the philosophical concept of the circle as a symbol of the universal nature and its division into quadrants to indicate the return to its origin. The text also talks about the correlation between the elements, plants and human life stages in four quadrants. In the last part (tokens 59 to 62), the author explains the transformation of fire, seed, and intelligent breath into air, water, earth, and physical bodies. The main corollaries of the evolution of the spirit into human form are also discussed. Saturn, the God who devours his children, and the symbol of a serpent eating its tail are also mentioned.
content: Il seme si muta in germoglio, in albero, in frutto. Il soffio intelligente (spirito) si muta in aria vitale (ibi = corpo aereo - corpo mercuriale) in acqua (corpo lunare) più' denso - Cristo -Anima. In terra (corpo umano terreno). 62) Come al n.57 la progressione dal minimo al massimo, e dal peggio al meglio si osserva nell'uomo nell'evoluzione dello spirito o principio incarnando fino al suo termine di uomo terreno, realizzazione e adattamento dello spirito. Da ciò' risultano una folla di corollari uno più' importante dell'altro eccone i principali: (1 Corollario - Lo spirito umano e' eterno) perché' riproduce se stesso in corpi diversi che egli stesso (principio) crea, cioè forma secondo fini determinati. Quindi lo spìrito di un uomo cambia corpi e involucri diversi, perché' nel suo ininterrotto cammino come il seme di una pianta riproduce se stesso. Il suo simbolo terreno gli antichi sacerdoti ponevano nelle mani di Saturno, il Dio che sbrana i suoi figli, e lo rappresentavano col serpente che mangia la sua coda (2 Corollario.
last_phrase: In conclusion, just as a seed grows into a sprout, tree, and fruit, the intelligent breath (spirit) transforms into vital air, water, and finally, the human body. This transformation is observed in the evolution of the spirit from its minimum to maximum state, as it incarnates into a human being. This results in various corollaries, with the most important ones being that the human spirit is eternal, and every human life is a mission determined by its informing spirit. Therefore, the happiness or unhappiness of a person corresponds to the fulfillment of their life's purpose, which is directed by their informing spirit. The informing spirit of a living being manifests itself in all its thoughts, actions, and achievements in the body it takes, and if this principle is beneficial, life is also beneficial.
